componenttext: But in 2012, it's less than 2011. Do you feel that domestically...

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's probably 185 now or something and it's probably going to go 120 or something.
componenttext: It's probably 185 now or something and it's probably going to go 120 or something.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Assuming that if it goes somewhat lower than that, do you think you could -- is there enough momentum in the rest of the business to have 2012 be at least and growth here?
componenttext: Assuming that if it goes somewhat lower than that, do you think you could -- is there enough momentum in the rest of the business to have 2012 be at least and growth here?

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. Let me put it this way. Sooner or later. If you look at the future's growth for crude, and that's a pretty deep market, and of course, the big guys don't play it, it's pretty indicative of what the market says the price is going to be and
componenttext: Yes, I think so. Let me put it this way. Sooner or later. If you look at the future's growth for crude, and that's a pretty deep market, and of course, the big guys don't play it, it's pretty indicative of what the market says the price is going to be and they're going to be pretty strong. And I think, I don't want to get into a peak oil discussion, but I think it's clear to me that it's going to be higher and more expensive incrementally to get more oil and the pricing is going to be better and it's going to be more rig intensive. And as I said in the presentation, things like Papua New Guinea are going to be in the picture. I don't even know when.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Algeria, the eight rigs there, seven of them are locked up through 2012.
componenttext: Algeria, the eight rigs there, seven of them are locked up through 2012.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: With new prospects there.
componenttext: With new prospects there.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Additional prospects and additional interest in other things that Gene referred to in terms of...
componenttext: Additional prospects and additional interest in other things that Gene referred to in terms of...

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Specifically, we have a little bit of an edge and availability of 3,000 hostile rigs just Middle East and not Africa, including Iraq. In fact, even in Iraq -- what the deal is, we're having to invest money there. And if you appreciate the money over 10 ye
componenttext: Specifically, we have a little bit of an edge and availability of 3,000 hostile rigs just Middle East and not Africa, including Iraq. In fact, even in Iraq -- what the deal is, we're having to invest money there. And if you appreciate the money over 10 years or 15 years, it's okay. But you're really working for three years just to get the incremental investment back, which is unfortunately the situation in Saudi now, too. But even in Iraq, we have high prospects of the jack-ups at decent margins, not the typical.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: What's the probability, are you closing one of these big divestitures this quarter?
componenttext: What's the probability, are you closing one of these big divestitures this quarter?

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think I'd be disappointed -- let me put it this way. My own probability assessment is in 90% that we have one of them, and all probability, Colombia, with deals firm, if not closed, by the end of the year.
componenttext: I think I'd be disappointed -- let me put it this way. My own probability assessment is in 90% that we have one of them, and all probability, Colombia, with deals firm, if not closed, by the end of the year.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Arun Jayaram with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Arun Jayaram with Credit Suisse.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gene, I want to talk to you a little bit about obviously what you can tell us on the sequential improvement in Sweezey? It looks like on a revenue basis, on an implied basis, the revenues were up by a mid 40% kind of percentage a quarter-on-quarter. So I
componenttext: Gene, I want to talk to you a little bit about obviously what you can tell us on the sequential improvement in Sweezey? It looks like on a revenue basis, on an implied basis, the revenues were up by a mid 40% kind of percentage a quarter-on-quarter. So I just want to understand how you generated that type of sequential growth? And on an implication basis, you're generating about $3 million per day in revenue, if you look at the last 20 days. So that implies that in 2011, you may be able to do $1.1 billion in revenue. So I just wanted to make sure I understand those components a little bit as we think about the earnings power of Sweezey in 2011.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I only looked at the whole year. Next year, I'm worried about what we do quarter by quarter. I'd say, they went from probably breaking even in the same calendar year, so maybe $280 to $300 approximates which has on it by itself has a margin probably 40% o
componenttext: I only looked at the whole year. Next year, I'm worried about what we do quarter by quarter. I'd say, they went from probably breaking even in the same calendar year, so maybe $280 to $300 approximates which has on it by itself has a margin probably 40% or something. So that market pricing has improved pretty dramatically. And I guarantee the pace of improvement won't continue and there's a risk of the whole thing. I mean, if we can stay where we are at now and kind of get some of it locked in more than a well frac-to-frac contract, that's what they're planning to do, and I think the only comment that what's the potential is are not crazy.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: So a potential of a little over $1 billion seems achievable if we can't continue at the same kind of run rate?
componenttext: So a potential of a little over $1 billion seems achievable if we can't continue at the same kind of run rate?

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: What does that give you in terms of gross margin income? I don't know.
componenttext: What does that give you in terms of gross margin income? I don't know.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: If we assume 20% kind of EBIT margins, it would be consistent with that, a little bit over $200 million.
componenttext: If we assume 20% kind of EBIT margins, it would be consistent with that, a little bit over $200 million.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there are risks to it. But I think it's fair to hold us to that standard.
componenttext: Yes, there are risks to it. But I think it's fair to hold us to that standard.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gene, I just want to get over expectations. You said for the E&P asset sales, you're comfortable with your thoughts. Is that still $1 billion on a pretax basis for both of those sales? Is that still what you're thinking?
componenttext: Gene, I just want to get over expectations. You said for the E&P asset sales, you're comfortable with your thoughts. Is that still $1 billion on a pretax basis for both of those sales? Is that still what you're thinking?

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sir.
componenttext: Yes, sir.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: My final comment or question is regarding the three jack-ups that roll over the next few months. What your expectations are? Are your expectations that you'll be able to keep the rigs working but just at lower day rates? And your confidence in the ability
componenttext: My final comment or question is regarding the three jack-ups that roll over the next few months. What your expectations are? Are your expectations that you'll be able to keep the rigs working but just at lower day rates? And your confidence in the ability to maintain utilization on those rigs?

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's it. I think we cut the sugar out of the margins, but expect it to work.
componenttext: I think that's it. I think we cut the sugar out of the margins, but expect it to work.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Jeff Tillery with Tudor, Pickering, Holt.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Jeff Tillery with Tudor, Pickering, Holt.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wondered if you could talk a little bit about packaging your Rig business with the pressure pumping offering? I just wanted some color on what was going on.
componenttext: I wondered if you could talk a little bit about packaging your Rig business with the pressure pumping offering? I just wanted some color on what was going on.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, I would guess calibrated by the way combining -- pulling through -- whatever is scarce you try to package with something that's not as easily marketed. So I wouldn't say we're going to have enormous success with that. But we're saying if we can
componenttext: Obviously, I would guess calibrated by the way combining -- pulling through -- whatever is scarce you try to package with something that's not as easily marketed. So I wouldn't say we're going to have enormous success with that. But we're saying if we can do it, if we can get an incremental rig or anything else with a relatively scarce frac-ing availability, we'll do it. I wouldn't say it's super significant yet.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: My second question is just on the Nabors' Lower 48 Land business. You mentioned in the press release leading edge rates well above the average rates you're realizing. Can you give us a feel for kind of normalizing for the asset class mix, how much headroo
componenttext: My second question is just on the Nabors' Lower 48 Land business. You mentioned in the press release leading edge rates well above the average rates you're realizing. Can you give us a feel for kind of normalizing for the asset class mix, how much headroom, leading edges above what the average rates you're realizing?

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, we're still seeing in the new bill opportunity day rates in excess of 25. Some of the existing assets we're starting to push, again, dependent on the market, we're starting to see some improvement in the legacy rigs. I can't tell you exactly what p
componenttext: Again, we're still seeing in the new bill opportunity day rates in excess of 25. Some of the existing assets we're starting to push, again, dependent on the market, we're starting to see some improvement in the legacy rigs. I can't tell you exactly what percentage we're converging, but we are seeing some improvement on those numbers results.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: My last question is just on the three international jack-ups. The one you're throwing this quarter and then it comes the first one in the spring next year. Is there work lined up for those? I'm curious, is there utilization risk on top of the day rate rol
componenttext: My last question is just on the three international jack-ups. The one you're throwing this quarter and then it comes the first one in the spring next year. Is there work lined up for those? I'm curious, is there utilization risk on top of the day rate rollovers? Just wanted a little color on that.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't think so. I'm pretty confident that they're going to renew.
componenttext: We don't think so. I'm pretty confident that they're going to renew.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010

componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Kurt Hallead with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gene, I take that if you were bearish on pressure pumping, you probably wouldn't have bought Superior when you did, right?
componenttext: Gene, I take that if you were bearish on pressure pumping, you probably wouldn't have bought Superior when you did, right?

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. The other thing is it pays to be lucky to get at the smart.
componenttext: Right. The other thing is it pays to be lucky to get at the smart.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: From a synergy standpoint, it seems like you guys made a lot of headway in a very short period of time with Superior. So kudos to you guys. And I'm assuming that was mainly on kind of a lot of the cost front. When you think through the revenue opportuniti
componenttext: From a synergy standpoint, it seems like you guys made a lot of headway in a very short period of time with Superior. So kudos to you guys. And I'm assuming that was mainly on kind of a lot of the cost front. When you think through the revenue opportunities on a basin-by-basin standpoint, one of the areas that I think you would agree sticks out is the Bakken, right? You guys have a big market share there. I don't think that Superior Well Services necessarily does. Two questions. Outside of the Bakken, where do you see the 11 new synergy opportunities? And then secondly, can you give us some general sense as to how we can tie back the number of frac crews needed per kind of rigs running?

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, generally speaking, the hot areas which are the Bakken, the Eagle Ford and the Marcellus are where the opportunities apply for both drilling, not only drilling, not only drilling, drilling works over hand of Bakken.
componenttext: I think, generally speaking, the hot areas which are the Bakken, the Eagle Ford and the Marcellus are where the opportunities apply for both drilling, not only drilling, not only drilling, drilling works over hand of Bakken.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to get a sense if we tie in to and connect the dots here between the number of rigs running and try to determine how many frac crews that might...
componenttext: I'm just trying to get a sense if we tie in to and connect the dots here between the number of rigs running and try to determine how many frac crews that might...

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the rule of thumb that I had is you need a frac crew for three rigs, roughly.
componenttext: I guess the rule of thumb that I had is you need a frac crew for three rigs, roughly.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's pretty much basin. It doesn't matter what basin you're in as you kind of look at that or is that Nabor specific?
componenttext: That's pretty much basin. It doesn't matter what basin you're in as you kind of look at that or is that Nabor specific?

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sure it does, but my rule is not [indiscernible].
componenttext: I'm sure it does, but my rule is not [indiscernible].

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, I just wonder if you might be able to give us some general sense, you have number of different discussions with E&P and so on. So where is your bias here? You think that the oil rig count will definitively more than offset natural gas? Obviously
componenttext: And then, I just wonder if you might be able to give us some general sense, you have number of different discussions with E&P and so on. So where is your bias here? You think that the oil rig count will definitively more than offset natural gas? Obviously, you've had some very good success in this business over a long period of time. What's your gut instinct tell you?

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: My gut instinct is that as gas price goes much lower, that balance is at greater risk. I don't know what it was today. It was like $3.30 or something. $3.29. I mean that's horrible. The ratio between gas and oil prices on a BTU basis, that's long gone his
componenttext: My gut instinct is that as gas price goes much lower, that balance is at greater risk. I don't know what it was today. It was like $3.30 or something. $3.29. I mean that's horrible. The ratio between gas and oil prices on a BTU basis, that's long gone history. But the long-term average was about 10:1. And now it's 25:1, something like that. Nobody ever asked me, but I'll assume you asked me, my position is that a number of things happen over a period of time that are unexpected. And if you look at what's likely to happen, like maybe the EP doing something uncool or Obama realizing that gas is not a swear word or any number of things, but I think the spread is multiple times more likely to contract than expand. So maybe in our business you got to be optimistic, but I think the odds are -- also, the other thing I've always said is I've never been involved in a situation where everybody's betting the same way and they make money. It doesn't happen.  But I'm still not personally buying in gas futures.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our final question is from the line of Roger Read with Natixis Bleichroeder.
componenttext: And our final question is from the line of Roger Read with Natixis Bleichroeder.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question, I guess, along the international side because a lot of the other stuff has been hit. If you look for, and I understand what's happening with international jack-ups, but if you look at the operations you have now, let's assume may be
componenttext: Just a quick question, I guess, along the international side because a lot of the other stuff has been hit. If you look for, and I understand what's happening with international jack-ups, but if you look at the operations you have now, let's assume may be a little recovery in Mexico and some progress in other international markets. Do you believe that the international segment has the potential to surprise you next year or is it just given the contract terms, timing, et cetera, that really is just going to be...

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right now, I know I'm always subjected to price, but I'd be very surprised if international makes a big headway next year. I'm willing.
componenttext: Right now, I know I'm always subjected to price, but I'd be very surprised if international makes a big headway next year. I'm willing.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if you could, where will it come from?
componenttext: And if you could, where will it come from?

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it has to be a place where -- if there's a new deployment, it's not going to impact next year very much.
componenttext: Well, it has to be a place where -- if there's a new deployment, it's not going to impact next year very much.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right, I guess it's more about where rigs rattle.
componenttext: Right, I guess it's more about where rigs rattle.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: It would have to be where we're at. We have Algeria. You have Mexico. But Mexico will likely -- Mexico has been sooner or later, but later not sooner, fortunately, I think this PEMEX situation is unrelated to the overall problem with government, with drug
componenttext: It would have to be where we're at. We have Algeria. You have Mexico. But Mexico will likely -- Mexico has been sooner or later, but later not sooner, fortunately, I think this PEMEX situation is unrelated to the overall problem with government, with drugs and all that stuff. But it's still an unresolved problem and it doesn't look like it's going to be in short-term results. But that's -- it would have to be either there or Saudi or...

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're 70% of the ratings. We'll contract 2011. So we have a good data and substantial number, protected contracts. And as Gene mentioned, the markets that have the multiple rigs, whether it's existing to PEMEX, extra rigs and extra infrasturcture offer th
componenttext: We're 70% of the ratings. We'll contract 2011. So we have a good data and substantial number, protected contracts. And as Gene mentioned, the markets that have the multiple rigs, whether it's existing to PEMEX, extra rigs and extra infrasturcture offer that potential, but there is a lot of delay.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you can bet on Nabors without betting that it's going to recover internationally next year.
componenttext: I think you can bet on Nabors without betting that it's going to recover internationally next year.

headline: Nabors Industries Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
